reviews: Worst hotel never had such a terrible experience in japan - must avoid!!!! Not helpful ppl at the reception!!! Not able to accommodate a differently abled person!! The room is barely fit for one person!!

Recently stayed here at mystays kamedio. 2 adult males. We had 9 nights booked here at what we thought was a great price. 2 beds a bathroom microwave fridge and only 30 minutes to Shibuya Crossing. We stayed 2 nights before we cancelled the rest of our stay to book at a different hotel.  This room is very small. With the beds together touching there is no room for the person against  the wall to go around to use the ‘airplane size’ bathroom. He or she must climb over the other persons bed.  The room has nowhere to put your suitcase to be out of the way. If you leave it on the floor you trip over it trying to move around. If you put it on the counter it blocks the tv or what little counter space is available.   The breakfast.  Not worth the money. There will be nothing there you

will like. And it’s $10-$15 per person per day. Don’t waste your money. There is a mister donut on your way to the subway stop there and grab a couple donuts for breakfast. It will be more satisfying. My friend just said the food is straight up disgusting. Fried eggs on ice is how he explains the eggs.   Positive note. The staff was awesome and the hotel refunded us for 7 of the 9 nights. there is a convenience store right outside the hotel.   If you read this and you still book this hotel. You have been warned.

Starting with the positive: The hotel is quiet, the location is a short walk to the subway and when you get the room it is clean. There is a convenience store across the road but it is usually picked clean if you go after 9 pm  The staff are friendly.   As for the rest of it: The room is ridiculously small given the price you pay , it is the size of a large bathroom. The bathroom is so small you hit the bathtub when you sit on the toilet. The room is not serviced during your stay and then there is a cleaning fee when you check out. A breakfast buffet is available but if you want a western style breakfast you are pretty much out of luck do he trays are usually empty of food.  The pictures on line do not accurately reflect the room.

i stay for a week,staff is friendly and the room is enough for my self,no have make up room (even a time for one week) but you can add aminities and change towel everytime if you want. bath room and toilet so small and highes then room,i dont like it. but not so far from kameido stasiun.

I’m a US traveler and booked this hotel for the New Years. The room is clean and priced right for the size. The staff are extremely friendly and assist when possible. The walk to the subway system was approximately 7 to 10 minutes. Hotel is 2 hours 8 minutes from Mt. Fiji by train. Hotel is 1 hour 25 minutes from Narita and Haneda Airport by train. Shinjuku-Ku and Akashi is approximately 40 minute train ride. We purchased the Suscia card for the train and put 4000 yen on each card. That lasted a four full days. Use cabs for really short trips cause they are expensive.

This hotel is rather hard to find. The building has no sign and it’s located in 7th floor. Just across the station and right next to mc donald.  When check in, the receptionist will ask you about your choise of breakfast. We chose western (bread, salad, egg) and what time you want your breakfast delivered to your room.  Only several room avaiable, so if you want to stay near the strategic area, it’s a good choice.  The room is local style, sleeping with ‘futon’ above the ‘tatami’. The facilities quite complete, hairdryer, towel, tv, ac, yukata, kettle and basic bath equiptment.  There’s no drinkable water avaiable, but you can buy them in 7 eleven near the hotel. There’re a lot of restaurant around if you are hungry.  Suprisingly, the breakfast is quite good. Smooth bread, fresh
salad with delicoius dressing and jelly for dessert.

A great hotel although not easy to find, it is on the seventh floor if I remember correctly and has no signage outside of the building it is in.  Very comfortable with european style beds, very clean and easy to use washing facilities for free which are great for travellers. Unfortunately there is no Wifi provided but this is easily rectified with the bar/restaurant next door which has free wifi.  Their website is not the easiest to use and did not want to accept my British postcode but if you can call them do that instead as their staff have good english and are very welcoming.  There is a station literally across the road from the hotel and if you want to stay somewhere nice and close to SHinjuku and Shibuya as we did, then this is definitely a great place to do it!

I stayed at the Tokyo Bay Ariake Washington for a week while on business travel. I wish I had paid attention to the reviews and looked elsewhere. There are other hotels close by and at comparable rates--I highly recommend choosing another property.  All the reviews that say the TBAW is dated and dingy are spot on. When I walked into the lobby to check in, it looked like a construction zone...but it wasn't. There are just racks of temporary shelves and a significant fraction of the lobby was roped off as bag storage. Like other reviewers, I was given a smoking room in spite of my non-smoking preference. I asked to change and was told no other rooms were available. I spent most of the night coughing, and again asked for a change the next day. Same story. I tried to check out and

find a different hotel but was told I would be charged for the entire week either way. So if the room makes you sick, too bad.  Beyond that, the property is just not cared for. The trash cans in common areas were often over flowing, vending machines were broken, and there were even empty beer cans on the table by the elevator for several days.   Was it the worst place I've ever stayed? No, but it was bad enough that I was willing to check out and try my luck finding another place to stay without a reservation.  The hotel responses to bad experiences feel disingenuous. I tried several times to resolve my issues and there was not even an attempt to help by the staff.

The hotel has small rooms, catering to the business traveler. Wifi is free and fast. There's a shuttle that runs to and from both airports.   Only 3-4 minutes walk to Big Sight. Immediate area has a few restaurants, plus a McDonald's.   Perfectly adequate if you are going to be working or attending a fair.

The hotel is situated just off the Big Sight exhibition centre and makes it an ideal choice when you want to visit any of the exhibitions because you just have to cross the pedestrian bridge. Unless you are looking for a spacious room, then this is not the right place for you. Rooms at the Washington hotel are tiny. They are clean and have big windows and come with an empty fridge and a small cooking plate where you can boil water (in case you fancy some noodles which you can buy in the convenience store just outside the hotel). The upper rooms towards the Big Sight building offer spectacular sunrise views (in case the weather cooperates). Reception staff speaks some English but most of the guests are Japanese, some come for the exhibitions, others to visit Tokyo Disneyland

which is not far away. The hotel is huge and can get rather busy, but there are plenty of elevators so you don’t need to wait too long. The basement restaurant serves buffet breakfast, but there are many other restaurant options in the same building or the nearby surroundings. If you like jogging, this area is nice, there are many trails without any cars nearby. Finally, there is a direct bus service to Narita and Haneda airports which comes in handy. Make sure to buy the tickets at the reception desk the night before, the buses can get crowdy.

Very convenient if you're going to the Big Site Center (5 min walk), but it takes 30 minutes on the monorail to get downtown. While there are a few restaurants in the hotel and nearby, the area around the hotel left me somewhat flat.   Rooms are standard size for Japan, and don't expect any amenities like a gym, a pool, or a lounge/bar. The TV system will allow you to buy a few movies in english, once you figure out the remote (Japanese), but don't look for CNN or any english regular TV. On the bright side, Breakfasts are included, each room offered internet access, and a few of the staff could converse in english.

Due to my flight times, I arrived at about 11am and they were very strict about no check-in until 2pm, but they happily looked after my luggage while I went for a walk round the area. When I eventually checked in, they were polite and welcoming.  I had a single room and it was very small, smaller than a budget hotel room in the UK. There was a desk but my chair was pressed up against the bed when sitting at it. The room though was clean and well kept.  The hotel breakfast was good, a wide choice of western and eastern styles.  The hotel does offer an in-room massage service, but this doesn't start till 7pm.I was already out for the evening each night by then, so never had chance to use it. I would probably have given it a go if it had been earlier.  I was there attending a

conference at the Tokyo Big Sight exhibition centre and it was very handy for that, just a short walk away. However, it was well away from the Tokyo night life and, with the train service ending around midnight, it meant you had to keep an eye on the time or risk an expensive taxi back. There is no night life in the area round the hotel.

restaurants.name: Seafood Restaurant Mexico, Tokyo Bay Ariake
Cafe Dining Umi No Onkei Grace de Mer Ariake Park Bldg
Doutor Coffee Shop Ariake Central Tower

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: Cons: No microwave in rooms even at their designated laundry/vending machine and ice room. Would be nice to warm up food that you buy from convenience and grocery stores. Need closet space in smaller rooms. Would be nice to have refillable container for shampoo, conditioner and body wash rather than having those small containers, it will be great for the environment. MANY Pros First: Location, Location, Location!!!! 3 minute walk from Shimbashi Station with at least 4 lines including the mostly used Yamanote line (even has an indoor underground access across the street to avoid rain), 3 minute walk to Ginza (2 blocks or just cross the train tracks) about 4 blocks to the street where they close the famous High End shop street on Sundays, Donki  Ginza is 5 minutes walk, countless

combinis (even have Lawson on second floor) Ichi**n, the famous ramen shop is just accross the Shimbashi station and the upscale version of the ramen place in Ginza is also few blocks aways. So much food option around the area! Second: Hotel Staff. They are the most accommodating staff especially the tall European young guy who's always ready to greet and so friendly.  The cleaning ladies are very friendly as well. I've visited Japan every year and most cleaning staff are very timid when a foreigner approach them but the The Blossom Hibiya staff are very courteous and polite and ready to help. Third: The room, we booked a corner room Deluxe Double. The highlight of the room is definitely the gorgeous view and the automatic window blinds that could even sync to the alarm clock! Everything is being controlled in a side table tablet! Room is always clean (kudos to the staff), the firmness of the bed is just right!  My husband and I also appreciated the 2 daily complimentary bottled water, wine opener, high quality wine and water glasses, not a huge fan of the UCC coffee maker (coffee was awful), I think you guys should change that to Nespresso. I also appreciate the daily tea! All and all, We found a new hotel that my husband and I will go regularly, we used to go to this high rise hotel in Shinagawa for the past 6 years but this hotel definitely impressed us. So much food option around! Two of my favorite desert Osaka's Pablo and Hokkaido's LeTao cheesecake is inside the station!!! We are definitely going back! I apologize if my review can be incomprehensible but hope the readers will get my point. ahahahah

Initially worried when I called from the States two months ago—no one spoke English well enough to assist.  Very pleasantly surprised that staff now are able to communicate fairly well.    Hotel and room look just like the website—clean, spacious enough for two although the standard king is tough to exit from one side of the bed since there’s only about 12” to wiggle through sideways....something to keep in mind.  And they reserve body lotion for the premier rooms.  Interesting.  Otherwise we had no issues with space except the safe—VERY small.  Big enough in width for iPad only.  Height is standard.  Located right across the street from a convenience store and within 10 min walk to major shopping in Ginza.  You can see the Imperial Palace from the window.  And the hotel is off

the near side of Hibiya Park.  Never took the metro but it’s also close by (walked past it).  Tokyo Station is 20 min walk.    They have a fitness room, laundry room and restaurant (no room service I think)—can’t comment on them personally.  Honestly I’m glad I didn’t spend the 1200/night at the Four Seasons!  This was a lovely hotel, boutique and modern.  And in a safe quiet area in the business section.    And Tokyo has Uber!  They cancel a lot but when you manage to get one, the drivers speak English.

Stayed in a standard room 9 nights in November. The hotel was just opened . Everything from arrival until departure was brilliant: location, staff, rooms super clean and functional, and above all the views from everywhere in the hotel. Thanks to the recpetion staff who allowed us to stay in the lobby until 10pm as our flight was late. P Masson

My husband & I had the best stay at The Hibiya Blossom for 5 nights. This new hotel in Shimbashi has everything you need within walking distance. Plenty of restaurants and bars , Shimbashi gets very lively in the night and is about 10mins walk to Ginza for great shopping too. Train station is around the corner so is easy to get around everywhere you want to be. All the rooms has great views of the city, is clean, spacious by Japan standards with a decent size bathroom that fit comfortably for most westerner. This hotels ticks all the boxes for sure; Location, accessibility, affordability and amenities. Highly recommended

Stayed for 3 nights over New Years.  It is new and modern.  The lobby is on the 25th floor with the rooms above that.  You do need to do the two elevator shuffle to get to your room.   The room was nicely furnished, and had a nice essentials in the bathroom - though the bathroom is on the small side.  Buffet breakfast had a lot of options, but lunch/dinner is Japanese food only.  We had a view of Tokyo Tower from our room, it is walking distance to Shimbashi Station and multiple subway stations.  We were also able to walk to the Imperial Palace.  Lots of restaraunts and bars in the area.

restaurants.name: Shabu Shabu Yakiniku Tabehoudai Merino Ginza
Sake to Koshitsu Izakaya Maguro Daihyo-dan ta Daihyo

reviews: definitely recommend this hotel. great value for the price.  very convenient location.  it is located 15 mins away by walk from harajuku and omamote sando; then 6 min by walk from the subway station (ginza line).  there is a lot of convenient stores around the hotel and restaurents as well. the room was small, as anywhere in japan and especially in tokyo, but functionnal and nicely decorated . loved the bathroom and the toto japanese toilet .  room and the hotel itself were recently furbished. i loved the aesthetic of the lobby and the room decoration as well.  air con and humidifier worked very well. bed was small but comfy.   there is a free onsen at the 10th floor.  great option to unwind . after a day of walking around tokyo.

This is a relatively new hotel, close to a subway stop and near the newly built Olympic stadium as well as baseball and rugby stadiums (I could watch a baseball game from my room).  Check-in is on the 9th floor, which is where the restaurant is, and the rooms are on the floors above.  There is a bit of a utilitarian feel to the lobby floor and restaurant, but the rooms, although small (to be expected for Tokyo) are well appointed and organized, if simple, and very clean (to be expected for Tokyo as well).  I had a room with a separate room for the toilet, whose lid rose as I approached it, and another room for the sink and bathtub/shower.  The lighting in the room was easily adjustable, and the room could be made quite bright.  The Wifi worked great.  There is also a

Japanese-style communal bath, as well as laundry machines, which were quite useful.  The staff was generally competent and efficient (again, to be expected of Japan). Because of the aforementioned sports facilities, there isn't a particularly commerical feel to the neighborhood in which the hotel is located, but there are more restaurants/shops closer to the subway station, and other areas of Tokyo are easily accesible via public transport.  I would definitely stay here again.

After a twelve hrs flight, we finally made it to Japan, landing at Haneda airport now the tricky part of our journey to our hotel begins, there is 3 option you have, a train, buses or taxis I have to admit selecting any one of these options and not knowing the language would be daunting but we were prepared for anything, and beside it wasn't fair on my wife dragging our luggage around so we opted for a taxi.  I must admit what I saw of Tokyo I was impressed wide and smooth road, a metro rail flying above us, and oh yeah, they have no litter bins, the pavement or sidewalk are so clean, how do they do it, put London to shame,  anyway we arrived at the NIPPON SEINENKAN HOTEL TOKYO, we were impressed by the layout, on the ground floor they have an American themed cafe,  the food was

good, the hotel rooms are small which I hear Japanese hotel are like this, the hotel restaurant  was reasonable and the price was affordable, the Japanese love their gadget, like self demisting bathroom mirrors and a toilet seat that open when they sense you, made me laugh, there is a train station 5 min walk called Gaiman, you will be impressed by this area, they have 3 stadium on that stretch of that road, and then you hit min metropolis amazing PLACE TO GO, Metropolitan govt building is free, and you can see japan from the 47th floors, spectacular view, sky tree is another attraction tall building but is not free, brilliant view, the subway is just easy to navigate and clean and the star attraction is the Shibuya crossing or the scramble crossing as we call it, japan is a fascinating country don't be put off by the language barrier, Japanese are happy to practice their English on you if the occasion arises. We will be going there again most definitely

Since this was a budget hotel, I was expecting bare accomodation. However, I was pleasantly surprised that the hotel was better than I expected. It was very clean, classy, and the famous Japanese toilet was awesome! The staff were very friendly and accomodating. Location was great, as it was just around the corner of the new Tokyo 2020 stadium. It was a bit pricey to be a budget hotel, but considering that this was Tokyo, the price was reasonable enough.

We had a nice stay at the Nihon Seinenkan Hotel. The hotel staff were very welcoming, and the hotel itself is beautiful- the lobby on the 9th floor overlooks one of the baseball stadiums, and it's a very bright, light-filled space. Our room was comfortable, although as a superior double it felt very small with our two suitcases (there were no good places to store them). The bed was not very comfortable, especially the pillows. However, the location was better than expected- it's about 10 minutes from Gaiemmae station, and it was a 25-minute walk to Shibuya and a 15-minute walk to Harajuku. We enjoyed our stay and would consider the hotel again the next time we visit Tokyo.

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: Very new hotel in a great location in Ginza. Easy walk to the subway and plenty of places to eat and shop in close proximity. Staff all welcoming, friendly and helpful. Bag drop off means you can go out and explore before your room is ready. Hotel looks great inside, especially for a mid-range hotel. Everything is spotless and the rooms are well appointed. You are provided with lots of bathroom amenities so you dont have to being lots of toiletries with you. Having the small seating area made a big difference to us as it is nice to be able to have tea/coffee or breakfast in your room and spread out your maps and guide books to plan the next days travels.  We would definitely make a return visit.

We stayed for one night. The hotel is modern, clean and in a central location within a few minutes walk of all the main shops and restatuants in Ginza. Its also less than 10 mins walk to the Tsukiji Fish Market.

The location was fantastic, right next to 2 subway stations (higashi ginza and ginza). Staff were welcoming and helpful. Unfortunately, the room was dirty and it was right next to a construction site.  Although the carpetting is very dark, it is very easy to spot when your shopping bags are stuck full of hairs (Static electricity) when you left it on the floor. Obviously the housekeeping is not vacuuming regularly. It can be quite noisy from 9am onwards as the construction site will start work.   Breakfast was decent, we get a set (3 to choose from) and a semi-buffet laid out. However, the semi buffet stopped in March due to the virus but that is understandable. Transportation to airport is very convenient as you can also hop onto the airport limousine at Courtyard Marriott
(opposite the hotel). Book it with hotel staff.

From the minute we arrived, we felt very welcomed.  Reception are great - really knowledgeable and able to help you navigate the metro system. The room was incredibly comfortable. So much so that one morning we completely slept in! Not a huge room but definitely had everything we needed. Very close to the metro and lots of restaurants and department stores in the Ginza area.

I had to wait about 1-1,5 hours prior to my check in due to some booking information misunderstanding with the front staff at reception, before finally I could enter the room. I also was advised to check my name as listed guest at another nearby Mitsui Hotel of which I did not do, instead I seat and waited at the hotel lobby and made several calls to my booking company in Jakarta, Indonesia. I was in Tokyo to attend a medical seminar for several days. Aside from that, the hotel was located in good location, close to Ginza station if you wish to travel to several destinations or even the airport, and close to shops and estaurants as well. There were several tourist attractions nearby. The room was small but standard, the breakfast was already set in different menu of which you

needed to make option. The room including bathroom was clean. Toiletries were available in the bathroom with shower, without bathtub. Overall, the hotel is recommended for people looking for place to stay in Ginza, Tokyo.

restaurants.name: Sake to Koshitsu Izakaya Maguro Daihyo-dan ta Daihyo
Tambagyu Club Rogama Sumiyaki Steak Ichimiya
Shabu Shabu Yakiniku Tabehoudai Merino Ginza

reviews: Our last 3 days in Tokyo we stayed here as a family our boys had their own room and we had ours they didn’t have anything bigger we struggled big time there was literally no room when you have two 30kg suitcases that you had to climb over to get out of bed and get to bathroom which was worse I couldn’t put my arms up to blow dry my hair that’s how small the nook was between shower and wall these rooms are for a person of 1 the only good thing was the location.

The room was small but seemed bigger than most we had stayed in Japan. Very clean and tidy. Good shower. The hotel staff were friendly. The location is great as we only had one night stay on the way to the MotoGP in Motegi. Recommend visiting the nearby Meiji Jingu Shrine. It was a bit of a trudge up hill to the station with backpacks but we managed ok. The staff would not let us check in early even though our room was ready. A little expensive for what you get.

This hotel exceeded my expectations. It is all new and nicely designed. The room was slightly larger than the average we had in Japan. The beds are comfy. It is located right in Shibuya. We walked to and from Shibuya St in 10-15 min.

Clean, modern hotel with all you need to spend couple of days in Tokyo. The rooms are quite small, so do not be surprised. But with good organisation you will survive. Good quality of cosmetics, hairdryer, tool kits and many, many more.  From the hotel by walk - just few minutes to most popular Shibuya cross-road. Aroud the hotel - coffee shops, restaurans and shops.  About 10 minutes to Metro and Train station

Perfect location with lots of shops nearby , 10 min form train station. Within walking distance to Shibuya and karajuku. A convenient store is right across the hotel.   The single room is quite small but clean with all the amenities needed . Good value for money.

夕食で唯一のレストランを7名で利用しましたが、他に数組のお客しかいないのに、最初の料理が出るのに40分(ナシゴレンとかカレーの類)、僕のグリルチキンは何と1時間。鶏肉を買いに行っているのか調理スタッフが不在なのかと思いました。空港直結のホテルとしては完全に失格、一からオペレーションを見直し、やり直すべきだと思います。 I strongly suggest not to use the restaurant because mf very slow service. Actually my grilled chicken came in a hour after order. It bothered me the people working there did not pay any attention to the customer like us although there were only few other customers.

I flew into the international airport terminal and needed to fly out the next day with JAL in one of the domestic terminals (terminal 1). This hotel is located at one end of Terminal 2. There is a shuttle between the three terminals. The staff were courteous and helpful, the room was clean, and the hotel was convenient. The breakfast buffet was one of the best that I have ever had. There was a nice mixture of Japanese, European and American food/drinks. I would definitely stay here again.

After a 13 hour flight and a one night stay in Tokyo we appreciated the convenience of Tokyu. We’ve stayed at other Tokyu brand hotels and have found them comfortable and clean.  This hotel is literally adjacent to the airport. The staff are friendly, helpful and courteous.   The breakfast buffet is good and well worth the add on. Be sure to include in reservation to save money.

My husband and I spent the last night of our vacation at the Haneda Excel Hotel Tokyo. We chose this hotel due to the proximity to the airport. It's actually in Terminal 2. Extremely convenient location. We arrived in Terminal 1. Cleared customs, collected our luggage and caught the free shuttle to Terminal 1 where we easily walked to the hotel. The room was on the small side. The breakfast buffet was mediocre but the location can't be beat for an overnight airport stay.

5 of us stayed in 2 rooms after a 1am arrival. Picked up bags, walked through customs, up a floor and hotel entrance was found easily. Quick check in allowed us to get much needed sleep ASAP. Appreciated complimentary bottle of water, comfy beds and clean functional bathroom. We were refreshed by 9am and able to easily face our onward train travels. Pillows were a bit weird but no other complaints. Highly recommended airport hotel.

restaurants.name: Cafe Nenrinya Haneda Airport No.2 Terminal
Wako 2nd Passenger Terminal Bldg. Haneda Airport
Starbucks Coffee Haneda Airport Terminal 2 South Pia
MMC Organic Cafe Narita Airport Terminal 2
Tops Haneda Airport No.2 Terminal Shokuhinkan
Godiva Haneda Airport Kin No Tsubasa

reviews: I’ve stayed at several MyStays properties and the experience had always been positive. However, it was very disappointing this time at Omori. The prices were not low and it was the premier range hence I definitely went with expectations. It was disappointing to see that the hotel was in an old property, seemingly like a refurbished flat/housing building. The interiors were much worse, very very old and dated. Perhaps the only saving grace was that it was decently near the train station but that’s about it. Would definitely not be back here again!

Tried to complain but neighbour is still noisy. Neighbour keeps banging the wall since 10:00pm and you can hear people talking. Noise is also heard from corridor which is annoying. Talked to online chat but it doesn’t really help. Don’t recommend this hotel.

Even though it’s a chain hotel , this one maintains a Japanese aesthetic especially in their rooms. I have forgotten how the lobby looks like but the slightly elevated from the floor king sized mattress was memorable. Housekeeping was spot on. Two days were not enough for me to get a sense of the neighbourhood though since we were on the train mostly.

The place is conveniently located  close to Omori Station and not far from City center. The hotel has all amenities and staff is very polite. There is a convenience store right in front of the hotel which makes this place even better to stay.

The shuttle service between HND airport and the hotel was NOT available in the afternoons, thus caused BIG inconvenience for us along with a child in both directions. I would not recommend someone at this hotel if they need the shuttle to HND airport!  Other than that, everything was fine!

restaurants.name: Irifune Western-Style Restaurant With Tatami Room

reviews: This area is not as lively as Shinjuku area were we stayed a few nights ago but there are some decent restaurants not to far from here.  The breakfast is very good.  The staff is very helpful and friendly. We would recommend staying at this hotel.

Great location, away from the centre of the city.  close to some nice restaurants and to the transport network.  Small rooms but they all are in Japan.  Staff were welcoming and very helpful and spoke English.  Would recommend

We had 3 nights in this very comfortable hotel. Room size decent- smaller than royal park in Yokohama  bigger than shiba park hotel Tokyo. Forceful shower over bath, beds firm, staff very attentive and respectful. Breakfasts very good but I didn't appreciate  the wait to get seated each morning. And the TV had only CNN which has to be the worst world news service ever. Please get BBC world news. Reasonable option to use lidobashi tube to Tokyo station then narita Express but watch out for getting lost in Tokyo station.

I really liked the hotel.  The room was very comfortable, super clean, super quiet.  I only had the breakfast one morning.  It was good.  There are lots of places to eat nearby and several convenience stores (Lawson and 7-11) and a Starbucks close by.  The hotel is between two subway stations and is easy to find.  I used Apple maps and you can easily find from the airports in Tokyo to the hotel via subway.  The staff was great and the room was super cleaned each day.

The staff at the hotel in this lovely quiet location of the city are very helpful and nothing is too much trouble. We had help with our bags at check in and were helped with any location/[planning questions. The breakfast at this hotel was one of my favorite parts of staying here! The rooms are very quiet and comfortable. Small of course but this is the city. Subway station just 7/8 minute walk and nice small restaurants within walking distance. would recommend and stay again!

restaurants.name: Japanese Restaurant Hirakawa Hotel Metropolitan Edmont Tokyo
Tully's Coffee, Iidabashi Garden Air Tower
Apa President Curry Iidabashi Station South

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: A friend recommended the Metropolitan Tokyo Marunouchi to us.  This hotel is much less expensive than other options we considered, and is extremely conveniently located -- adjacent to the central Tokyo train station served by the Narita express and bullet trains from other parts of the country.  We stayed for three nights in a corner room which offered fantastic views and made the admittedly small room seem larger and airier.  Though less luxurious than rooms at hotels like the Four Seasons and Mandarin Oriental, the room was immaculate, well-appointed and comfortable.  The staff was extremely helpful.  This is an excellent option for a short stay in Tokyo.

I liked the hotel's location, right above Tokyo central station. I chose it because we had to take an early morning train to Kyoto, and this allowed us at least +1 hour of sleep. We chose the cheapest room, which was small but fully equipped and with a nice modern decor. As opposed to other hotels, where cheap rooms have ugly views, this one had a very large window on a spectacular view of Tokyo. PC with Internet connection were available in a small business centre, but with charge. Overall, a very good value for money (Euro 120 for the double room).

Stayed in a Deluxe single at the Metropolitan Marunouchi for 6 nights on business, booked through the Japanese website Rakuten. For someone requiring a base around Tokyo station for travelling around Kanto - it must be hard to beat this hotel at the moment. Finding the entrance to the hotel was a bit of challenge, but more down to navigating to the correct exit from the station. Staff were friendly and attentive, hotel immaculate (opened in May 07) and service top class. Breakfast was a buffet and plenty of choice, the rooms were quiet and there was no noise leakage from the train tracks below. Free in-room internet was a nice bonus, and the selection of amenities was good though fairly standard for a Japanese hotel of this grade. Room size was perfectly adequate, par for the

course for central Tokyo - fittings and furnishings good quality. There are plenty of food options in the neighbouring buildings and nearby areas.  Overall, highly recommended as a base for business and tourists alike.

Name is watanabe! I gave 2 stars because the rest of the staff were great because of this person I would never stay at this hotel ever again. This person is just a disgrace to the service industry! 830am reached the hotel check in counter instead of trying to help me check in he displayed the worse n rude attitude! Come on if your hotel don't have room for early check in I perfectly understand, don't have to give me the attitude n rude treatment!

That this was a small room wasn't a surprise -- but having a double bed pushed against a wall .. so that the second person had to vault over the first in order to leave the bed -- that was unusual at best. And not fun to live with.

restaurants.name: Kuzushi Kappo Platinum Fish Sapia Tower
Ginza Wine Shokudo Papa Milano Sapia Tower
Starbucks Coffee Tokyo Station Sapia Tower
Tempura Keyaki Tokyo Station Kitchen Street
Din Tai Fung Tokyo Station Yaesu Entrance
Bar of Tokyo Manouchi Trust Tower
cusines: Brew Pub, Pub, Dining bars, Beer restaurants

restaurants.name: Starbucks Coffee JR Tokyo Station Nihonbashi Entrance
Shabu Shabu Yakiniku Tabehoudai Merino Ginza

reviews: RICHMOND HOTEL PREMIER TOKYO OSHIAGE Richmond Hotel Premier Tokyo Oshiage is an unpretentious, modern premier hotel with 260 guest rooms in the immediate vicinity of Tokyo Skytree. The hotel has a popular buffet reception and premium bedding for a comfortable hotel life during your stay. The location was great if you could see the Skytree, but other than that, the rooms were clean and luxurious, and it was the best hotel recommended for everyone, including the room rate.  リッチモンドホテルプレミア東京押上 は… 5階から上層階に260室の客室があり  人気のバイキング形式のレストラン＆バー Sizzler  24時間対応のフロントや高級寝具シモンズ製ベッドが備わり 快適なホテルライフを過ごせます 毎日のハウスキーピングで室内は清潔感があり居心地が良く 東京スカイツリーまでは歩いてすぐで観光地浅草などにも近く 静かなロケーションは熟睡するのに最適の場所 全てにおいて快適な素晴らしいおすすめのホテルです

Good location next to the sky-tree in Tokyo. Large room, clean and comfortable.  2 different local train station within 2-3 minutes walk from the hotel.  Big shopping mall and plenty of restaurants below the hotel.

The hotel is just across from Sky Tree and related shopping area. It is above a big and convenient supermarket.  The hotel staff could speak English well enough to handle my needs and were very helpful. The hotel was clean and had lots of amenities. The bathtub was also full size.  It was a great staycation! When friends or family visit Tokyo in the future I will recommend this hotel highly.  I was more than satisfied!!

Date: October 21st, 2020 Type of travel: solo - preflight  Type of room booked:  Double room non smoking   This is a very nice property, conveniently located in front of Soramachi, the mall next to Tokyo Sky Tree.   Has two stations nearby.   Tokyo Sky Tree, in Tobu Tokyo Sky Tree Line (~7  minutes walking )  Tokyo Metro Oshiage (crossing the street) this line connects with Narita and Haneda Aurport.  Transportation to airport via Tobu  Bus (~ Minutes walking)   Rooms are decent size and well kept.  Check for the beautiful bottles of water they provide. Rooms with very good view     Front Desk at 5th floor of the building.  Very good supermarket in the basement.

Location of the hotel is very good, in Sumida City, right next to public bus station and opposite the subway station „Tokyo Skytree“ and impressive Tokyo Skytree (tallest structure in Japan with height of 634 metres and one of the tallest structures in the world). We spent there five nights in Superior Twin Room (plus two extra beds for children) with direct view over the Tokyo Skytree broadcasting and observation tower. The only problem was a size of the room that was not sufficient for four persons, but as we have been spending a majority of time in the city it was not a big deal. On the the other hand price for the accomodation was very reasonable, buffet-style breakfasts in hotel's restaurant Sizzler good as well. We have not visited that reastaurant for the dinner as the

offer seemed to us limited and prices for meals inadequate. But there is plenty of restaurants with different cuisines in nearby Tokyo Skytree building. The additional advantage of the hotel is a large supermarket that is located on the ground floor.

restaurants.name: Gion Tsujiri Tokyo Sky Tree Town Soramachi
Sugimoto Main Shop Tokyo Sky Tree Town Soramachi
Nanas Green Tea Tokyo Skytree Town Solamachi
World Beer Museum, Tokyo Sky Tree
Komatsuan Main Shop Tokyo Sky Tree Town Soramachi

reviews: A nice hotel with everything you need.  The rooms are typical of Japanese hotels at this range, fully functional with all the expected amenities (even a shirt press in the room) but nothing extra.  There is a free wireless hotspot in a corner of the lobby tucked away by the vending machines.  There are also computers available which charge 100 yen/10 min of internet.  The staff is polite and helpful (as in most Japanese hotels) and they speak English and English maps are readily available.  The area is quiet, not exciting really but a high class area and a short walk from a small shrine.    It is a good 15 minute walk to the JR Shimbashi station but a 7 minute walk to the Kamiyacho and Onarimon Tokyo Metro and Oedo Mita line stations.

Having spent a pleasant week in Tokyo, staying in a very small but comfortable room at the Tokyu Inn, we needed to use the laundry service on our last day. In the morning we dropped off our laundry and asked if we could pay upfront, to which we were told was not possible. Upon collecting our laundry we were footed a bill for around 21,000 yen (£123) for a few t-shirts and dresses. Whilst I completely understand it is our fault for not checking a price list, when I simply asked if that bill was correct, suddenly the man became incredibly rude and agitated, and started angrily and deliberately hitting the keys of his calculator with force, frowning at us and throwing it down on the desk like a child. Considering how polite and helpful everyone has been in Tokyo we found his

behavior to be incredibly rude and not reminiscent of the general attitude of the city. We thanked him for checking again merely to be greeted with what can only be described as a 'dirty look' and no response. It may seem minor but being addressed like an idiot after essentially being completely ripped off sullied our view of this hotel.

The hotel is located in Shimbashi area, best way to reach is either by Narita express to Tokyo Station and then onto Subway to either Shimbashi (15min walk) or Toramonon station (10min walk). I would suggest against using taxis unless you have no other choice or simply can afford it!   The room was clean and compact as i expected from my research on hotels in Tokyo, since i was solo this wasnt a problem and i never faced any issues in terms of space. I never took the breakfast package but instead had it in Shangri-la next door, if you book in advance its 1200Yen, if you pay at the door its 1400Yen. The staff where very helpful and polite. The room has no safe but i deposited my valuables with the desk which they put into a safe so its good enough. They still have an old key

system but thankfully you do not need to carry this around as you can deposit it when leaving and collected when you arrive back (the front desk is open 24 hours with at least 3 members on at all times).   The area is fairly quiet compared to some areas in Tokyo so if youre expecting a hussling and bustling night life you will surely be mistaken, that said there are plenty of shops restaurants and coffee places nearby to keep you entertained, Shimbashi is 15mins walk and plenty of small bars and restaurants there.   Night life is mainly in Roppongi and Shinjuku, Roppongi is only 1 stop from Kamyacho station on the Hibiya line, the station takes less than 7 mins to walk from exiting the hotel. You can also connect to Shinjuku from Roppongi on the Oedo line. To be fair the subway system is so well connected you can reach anywhere in Tokyo within 25mins. Only downside is if you are out after midnight you will need to catch a cab (that will burn a hole in your pocket if in Shinjuku and staying here)   All in all it was a nice place to stay considering the price i paid and the size of my room its most definantly worth it. Would most certainly stay again if im back in Tokyo.

I have just returned from a 6 day night stay in Tokyo and for the price we paid, I wasn't disappointed with the Tokyu Inn hotel.  The hotel is in a good location with three subway stops all within a 10 minute walking distance. We often used the Ginza line so having Toranomon on the doorstep was extremely useful. If you choose to take the Skyliner from Narita airport to the terminus at Ueno, you can easily transfer to the Ginza line ( which is also at Ueno), making the trip to and from the airport manageable and affordable. The hotel is also only 10-15 minutes walk to Shinbashi station which has plenty of restaurants to eat in. I enjoyed exploring the local area, Tokyo tower is just down the road as are many beautiful shrines and temples.  I arrived in Tokyo very late at night,

but contacted the hotel the day before my arrival to warn them about my late check in. The staff were expecting me when I arrived at around 1am and check in was quick and easy. The rooms were small but adequate. The double size bed was slightly on the small side but we managed ok. The bathroom was again small but had everything you could possibly need. Shampoo, conditioner and shower gel came in big bottles which was much better than the usual small bottles provided in hotels.  I was also pleasantly surprised to find that the reception provided me with wifi passwords for the hotel room, which I wasn't expecting after reading previous reviews. The only slight issue  I had with the room was that it was quite hot and the air conditioning didn't seem to be very effective. This wasn't too much a problem in April but it would have been in the summer months.  Finally breakfast was better than imagined. The selection comprised of Western ( pastries, egg, sausages, cereals, fruit etc) and Japanese food. We left breakfast full every morning so no complaints there. Breakfast was very busy around the 7am mark, so if you can afford to go a little later it is much less crowded.  All in all a good stay for a city break as long as you're not expecting massive rooms with 5* service.

We got this hotel using air miles but we would not recommend staying here unless you had to or it was free/cheap. The room was extremely small with no storage space and only two hangers to hang your clothes on the wall. The room was extremely dusty and nobody had cleaned under the bed in a very long time. We can only work of the room we stayed in, which was in the older building. We asked to change but was politely told we could not. Location wasn't bad as Shinbashi station was only a 10 minute walk away or 25 minutes taxi to Shinjuku (3000yen) We stayed in far nicer hotels in Tokyo and would recommend paying a little more for one of these. Plus point was free wifi in the lobby which is surprisingly not common in Japan.

restaurants.name: Sake to Koshitsu Izakaya Maguro Daihyo-dan ta Daihyo
Shabu Shabu Yakiniku Tabehoudai Merino Ginza

reviews: I love this hotel, its clean, spacious, restaurant is huge.  Peter Chen is the best manager, he's constantly improving the hotel and organising fun events.  There are a few Sakura hotels in Tokyo, this one has the best food, and bigger rooms - I especially like the Japanese Tatami rooms which are spacious with lots of natural light.  The restaurant staff are super friendly too - and food is cooked fresh at reasonable prices - I love the Taco rice !  Will definitely wish to stay here longer next time :)

Location good,clean enough but it is true the walls somewhat dirty.I wiped with a wet tissue and it came off ,so no big deal to clean it. Otherwise everything ok ,surprised people could complain about the breakfast,for that price you are lucky to get anything.

I regularly use Sakura Hotel Nippori to do business as it has reliable wifi and great facilities. The cost is extremely reasonable and staff are helpful. The location is great, it's right in the heart of the trendy Yanesen district and very convenient for both Nippori and Sendagi stations, making it easy to get from Narita airport and travel around Tokyo. You can even visit Ueno park and its many museums on foot.  The rooms are simple and clean. The restaurant has a wide variety of international cuisine and a great selection of world beers. I would equally recommend this to people traveling around Japan, or for those who need a teleworking base.

Exactly what you would want from a hotel for travelers who stay on the GO: great convenient location, helpful and friendly multi-lingual staff, delicious and affordable in-house cafe, and room options to suit your needs. I've used a few Sakura House hotels both on my own and with friends and they've always been more than accommodating. The manager, Peter, was super friendly and helpful in seeing that I had the best experience during my stay.

We went with friends, very nice place with all the Covid-19 measures, nice staff they speak English, Spanish and Chinese, and very good food, close to Yanaka Street and JR Yamanote line, perfect for a visiting Tokyo, the rooms are very confy and clean and a very tasty breakfast, wonderful time there.

We reached Pearl Hotel Kasai using Airport Limousine Bus (Keisei Bus) from Narita Airport T2. Just buy ticket at the counter arrival area. I checked the  bus timing before hand in their website so it went smoothly. We arrived in the hotel at 2:00PM almost 1.5hrs travel from airport. Check in time is 3:00PM and fortunately given our room key as soon as we arrived though 1hr early. I was glad that our room was big with 4 beds and a closet though I booked only standard twin room. No complimentary bottled water but they offer it for free if you will not ask for housekeeping everyday. We availed the offer but on the 3rd day we ask for cleaning the room. We stayed for 7 nights. With free shuttle going to Disney and need to booked/reserved but NO pick up from DLR to hotel but they

provided print out instructions on how to get to DLR and bus stations going back and forth to the hotel which was a big help since there was japanese writings on it just show the paper when asking.  No bell service. You bring your own luggage to your room and when checking out. The staff were courteous and attentive to our needs even on booking queries thru Agoda you can inquire to them directly such as request for a non smoking room and the likes..  Breakfast included was a big factor before going out. A suffice buffet menu. Their fried chicken in small size was our favorite.  Overall this hotel is recommended for budget traveller going to DLR for 2 days or more and for those who go out most of their stays since the location can be easily access by train and bus to any point of Tokyo tourist spots.

The hotel is a short walk from the train station. It is conveniently located near restaurants and convenience stores. This is especially helpful because the hotel does not have its own food outlet. Disneyland is close. You can take a cab to Disney Sea for a little over Y2,000.  The room was small, just enough for two people with luggage. We tried to ask for a non-smoking room but the hotel was full. The front desk gave us a spray bottle to use for masking the smell of smoke in the room. We sprayed everywhere, especially on the curtains, carpet, bed and pillows. Otherwise, it was a comfortable and pleasant short stay.

Close to the subway station, and easy access to convenience stores.  Staff is helpful and friendly but English is limited.  Rooms are clean, small, and affordable. Breakfast buffet selection is great!  The Wifi worked and there were two computers in the lobby that could be used.    The free shuttle to Disney only goes in the morning!  It's about an hour walk if you don't take the subway.

This hotel is in a suburb of Tokyo near tokyo Disneyland and Odaiba. Hotel seems old. There was mold on the bathroom door area. The room actually had a strong urine smell. Staff not very friendly and I do not recommend this hotel.

The hotel is clean, located in a quiet suburb of the city so takes a while to get into the heart of the city. The rooms are small but ok and very clean. Toilets good and immaculate. Food is good too in the restaurant and buffet complimentary breakfast is very good.  You need to speak a little Japanese though as the staff though very nice and courteous speak very little English.  I had a pleasant stay!

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights in Rm 522 in late march of 2020.  I stayed here as part of a tour group going around Japan.  The hotel is in a great location.  It is only about 500 meters or so from the Ginza shopping street.  There are plenty of restaurants and stores around as well.  There is a 7-Eleven very close that is above a convenience store but just below a mini market.  You can find lots of prepared foods there such as sandwiches, pizzas, etc.. there.  There is also an ATM in the 7-Eleven that will accept foreign ATM cards since not all bank ATMs in Japan accept foreign cards.    If you go out the back of the hotel and turn left and keep going in that direction you will hit a wide river which has a nice walk along it.  I saw men fishing from the side.  You will

pass I think it was called St. Lukes hospital(thats right is has an English name).  The hotel is located off the streets but taxis can get to it but not buses.  There are two alleys that angle out the front of the hotel to a street.  This is the direction you want to go for nearby restaurants and the 7-Eleven.  The hotel has a good size lobby that is spacious in Japanese terms.  You can tell this is above a 3 star hotel by just seeing it.  That is my opinion.  The hotel has a restaurant on the 2nd floor.  I had all my breakfasts there.  They will give you a choice of Western or Japanese breakfast.  The breakfast was good though their eggs are cooked a way I am not used to.  The rest was goodl, especially the croissant.  I am not certain if they serve other meals but I would not be surprised if they did.  Upon entering my room my bathroom is on the right.  It has a sliding door that closes off the bathroom.  Inside the bathroom the shower is on the right.  Entering the shower you come immediatley to the shower portion with has a choice of a hand shower head or the shower head in the ceiling.  Next to the shower and only accessible via the shower is the Japanese style bath tub(sort of like a half American bath tub with higher walls).  In the shower you have access to large bottles of bath gel, shampoo, and conditioner.  The bath towels are right above the bathtub after I looked around.  The shower and bathtub are enclosed in see-thru plexiglass.  Same as the shower door.  Going past the bathroom you come to the bedroom with the queen size  bed on your right.  On the left side of the side(furtherest from the bathroom) there is room to easily move around.  The right side if I recall is virtually against the well.  I did not see any electrical outlets next to the bed but there are light switches for the room.  Opposite from the foot of the bed is a counter with the LCD TV on top of it.  In the corner near the window is a typical hotel desk.  There is a row of Type A(two prong) American type plug in(standard in Japan).  I would say you could plug in at least 3 in the row if you wanted.  The TV had only Japanese stations on it except CNN but it was being dubbed in Japanese.  There were options on the TV to watch movies, etc. on it as well  I forgot to mention there is a small refrig under the counter where the TV is located.  It is empty and you can put some things in it.  Overall, this was a very nice hotel to stay at in a great location where you can walk around.  I would certainly stay here again.

This hotel is very close to the metro Tsukiji Station and the Tsukiji Fish Market and walkable to many shops and restaurants as well as local attractions. The rooms are on the small side but there is still room for your belongings. Very clean! The breakfast buffet has a large selection and there is something for every taste. The beds are firm (hard)  and the gym is very small (but present). The staff try very hard although very limited English. We actually booked extra nights there on our way out of Tokyo Japan following touring about the country.

Stayed here for a few days for a work trip and it is a good business traveller hotel near the train station. Its also very near a couple of cafes and a 24-hour Denny’s restaurant is just a few meters walk away. It is also near many restaurants at the Tsukiji Outer Market. So no shortage of fresh sushi for lunch and dinner.  For those of you less familiar with the wholesale Tsukiji Market - it moved out a couple of years ago but the surrounding restaurants and food stalls are still there and the food is fresh and readily available.  The photos attached are taken at the nearby the hotel: a Buddhist temple (I forgot the name) and at the Tsukiji Outer Market.

We had a great stay in this hotel and we give a thumb up. We stayed here for 3 nights. The hotel is modern, clean and comfortable. It is located just 5 minutes away from Tsukiji Subway station. I would advise if you are coming from Tokyo station, take a JE Keiyo line to Hatchobori Station and changed to Hibiya Subway line to Tsukiji Subway Station.  Tsukiji market is not far from the hotel which you can enjoy all the lovely food.   Highly recommended.

Nice cosy room, rooms are small but you can store your  luggage at reception if you need more space. Staff are friendly & helpful. Housekeeping are excellent, rooms are so clean and neat everyday. We had 3 beds and its awesome for a family. Price was decent, location is excellent, so close to train. Only one issue i had was the toilet went crazy and started squirting water everywhere even though i didn't press any buttons, it only happened once but i've never experienced that before anywhere.

restaurants.name: Shabu Shabu Yakiniku Tabehoudai Merino Ginza
Tully's Coffee Tsukiji St. Luke Street
Flora Ginza Capital Hotel Main Building
Cafe de Crie Tsukiji Seiruka Dori

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: The location conveniency is great , my checking in took too much time and forever, I guess my room wasn't ready and instead of offerring me a seat to while preparing my room,this Guy keep on doing some kinda talking delays and i stood for like 30 minutes and realize the huge line after me and besides me were all checked in. What a stress! 💔front Desk is absolutely unprofessional , need more training. Room atmosphere not bad , But Tea cups in the guest room should have handles, you cant carry or handle it after preparing Tea, so useless! Breakfast was good with clean atmosphere, variety of food and Beverages , Hotel Needs English speaking staffs too, seems like don't have interest in foreigners , very heart breaking.

I thoroughly enjoyed my month at the Shinagawa Prince hotel. I was there for the Olympics so there were covid measures in place. All very well handled.  My room in the annex tower was great with superb convenient location, a good view, great WiFi, comfy bed, ample storage, daily bedding and towel change, free bottled water, fridge, hairdryer, toiletries and a great shower.  The only drawbacks were not much English speaking TV and breakfast for quarantine (fourth floor) got very boring, after quarantine it was superb on ground floor in main tower.  The staff were all very helpful and friendly.  I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend this hotel.

This trip happened in Nov 2019. Hotel is a traffic light away from Shinagawa Station and is one of the hotels for the Airport Limousine route. We booked a room (corporate rate) in the Main Tower and was given the Corner Room with Sofa Bed which costs around $300/night.   Room is rather squeezy (but seems to be the norm for hotels in Tokyo) and a little old with minimal space to open up luggages. Toilet was small but came with full toiletries. Room had kettle, small fridge, hair dryer but no bottled water. Hotel has a shopping mall of its own with a food court, entertainment complexes and various shops and other hotel wings. There are restaurants located opposite and around the area of the hotel too but requires travelling by shinkansen or metro line to tourist spots in Tokyo.

All the self-check-in machines were not available, so the guests had to wait more than half an hour in a long line before check-in. Even under the circumstances of Corona pandemic, they should have found a way not to waste guests‘ time. The room had nothing special to be mentioned.

I stayed late February - just before the Covid -19 lockdown - again at the Shinagawa Price Hotel. Everything was as great as always. The quiet room, as well as the perfect service. A special Thank You to the attentive Front Desk. I arrived into Haneda - which is just 15 train minutes away - and left from Narita. This time I took the Airport Limousine Bus back to the airport. Highly recommendable. After less than an hour nonstop from the lobby, the bus drops you at the terminal .

restaurants.name: Art Coffee Branche Keikyuu Wing Takanawa
Mango Tree Cafe Plus Bar Shinagawa

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: The room was great but the service was rather poor. We tried to cook but forgot buying salt and pepper. We asked the hotel to share some from the restaurant but they refused. I think they should at least try their best not to say no to hotel guests.

I stayed here on business in November for a week. The self serviced apartment had everything I needed and was a lovely size, bed super comfy and linen gorgeous. I had an issue with not understanding the washing machine but thats to do with my ineptness. The whole building is beautiful and effortlessly run. I loved it and was so close to the office for me. The pool is a saving grace too, its open til 10pm so was good to get a swim in every evening before bed to help with the jet lag.

Great location (for us at least); very clean rooms with high quality fixtures, appliances, bedding, toiletries, etc; helpful staff. Great view too facing the imperial palace gardens. I would definitely stay here again... the amount of space and amenities really helped make the trip comfortable for 2 people.

Very large room for the price. Extremely well maintained and clean. Awesome bathrooms/showers. Very very friendly and helpful staff who assisted us with restaurant bookings and advice. In a very good location, and the view from our apartment on the 28th floor overlooking the imperial palace and gardens was spectacular.

Stayed here as a Platinum Ascott member. Location great - near Tokyo Station and therefore lots of different dining options from cheap and cheerful to high class. Check in fast and efficient. Upgraded a room type due to Ascott status so a very positive start to the stay and hard to go backwards from there!  Room was big and spacious and very well decked out. Huge bathroom with bath, with great amenities. Beautiful view over the area from the 25th floor. Comfortable beds. Well appointed kitchenette.   Only real gripe is that while the furniture is relatively tasteful and functional, the decor is a bit twee - reminds me of a professional Airbnb fit out, especially the wall hangings which I suspect are identical in every room. Hallways also have pretty ugly carpet and trimmings,

but the lobby and shared lounge and outdoor area were actually very stylish.   Pretty nice gym, and a small indoor infinity 'gym' pool which is closed to children.  Would stay again happily, but maybe more of a business hotel than a family hotel.

restaurants.name: Shabu Shabu Yakiniku Tabehoudai Merino Ginza
Sake to Koshitsu Izakaya Maguro Daihyo-dan ta Daihyo

reviews: I just got back from 2 weeks staying at the Flexstay Inn Tokiwadai. It was just as the first time, if not better given that this time around I was familiar with the area. 24h Mc Donald is just around the corner, as well as Fuentes (supermarket, closing at 2 am). There is an amazing onsen a 20 min walk away (Menoara onsen). I highly recommend this place!

The location is outside the Tokyo metro. The area outside the Station is nice they have convenient store and fast food restaurant. The area is quite except the street or maybe highway in front of the hotel that is never quite. The room is quite big because I can put 2 luggage down on the floor and still have the space to walk.

I stayed here for 2 weeks, though most of the staff doesn't know too much English, every time I need it something they were more than willing to help, Wifi is really bad most of the times but that happen to me in almost every place I went to Japan.  I do like the area, is a lil bit far from the Tokyo Centre, still is quite easy to get to any area you want since the Japan metro is awesome!.  Also you can see hotel from the train so it was really easy to find.  There is a supermarket near by, a small plaza where I get to see some free cultural presentations, fast food restaurants, a 7 eleven, it is a residential area, so if you want to see local living, this is the place.  What I do think was hard was the smoke smell, it does not come off no matter what you use (actually all rooms
are smoking rooms, just that I did not think it will be this hard smoke smell).  Avoid rooms facing the avenue.  Other than that, I could stay here again.

On this visit we chose a 3 person room for a 9 day period, november 7th til november 16th, before travelling to kyoto and returning for another week in Tokiwadai with Flex Stay. The staff are incredibly helpful and polite, without being pushy or intrusive, the location is as always ideal, and after experiencing various other short term accomodation throughout Kyoto and Ikebukuro, Flex Stay Inn will, in future, always be my first choice of accomodation. The view from the rooms are beautiful, the amenities highly improved to now include a toilet seat warmer, bidet function, and free wired and wireless internet with incredibly high speed and strong connection. See other review for more information.  Newly discovered to me is also a small bakery parallel to the train tracks run by

an eccentric man who makes incredible food. The bakery's location is noted on a map given to you upon checking in at Flex Stay Inn, with various other useful information.  Beds also are extremely comfortable and air conditioning heats well on cold days.  Will definitely be staying again and would recommend this place to anyone looking for affordable, comfortable accomodation in Tokyo.

Cosy rooms, perhaps a little small to some but for standards in Japan, quite large. They have well tended facilities and great proximity to the Tokiwadai station, a Sukiya, Mos Burger, McDonalds, bakery, pizzeria, bento sushi store, convenience store and more - all within a 5-10 min walk at a leisurely pace. Right nearby is also a beautiful ramen store seemingly operated out of someone's home with the kindest family and best ramen I've experienced in Japan. The hotel itself is well operated with good staffing and access, however the staff will tend to leave you to your own devices - to some a negative aspect, to me a valid manner, particularly appropriate to the Japanese atmosphere. Price-wise this place is fantastic to stay for anywhere under a month, and being only a 15-20
minute ride from Ikebukuro with trains every 5 or so minutes at peak hour, you can hardly find better for short stays.  Staying again on November 7, and will be again afterwards.

restaurants.name: Gyoza no Manshu Tokiwadai Nort Entrance

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
Photo copier / fax In business centre
reviews: Went here  in 2012. It is right next to the temple which was used in the Wolverine Movie. The view from the bar at night is mindblowing. Staff wouldnt let me check in early so I had to wander around Tokyo at 6 am , first time there, what an experience.

Very nice place, quite and close to everything, with many facilities like transportation...nice stuff, clean rooms with Tokyo tower view which was amazing, they have even shops inside the hotel and a small market, and you can visit a lovely bakery just steps from the hotel inside a lovely garden called “Le Pain quotidien” you will enjoy their fresh an tasty bakeries with warm Japanese tea and they have also lunch menu...Friendly young stuff, Must try.

Beautiful hotel that you can visit other two hotels and use some of the facilities. This will be the hotel we will stay when we visit Tokyo. Room is clean, bed is comfortable, staffs are professional.

My wife & I stayed here between 26th February-01 March 2020. It was my first visit to Tokyo although a shock to the system ( Tokyo) we live in the country it’s very quiet. The Hotel was fantastic we had a corner king room a great location the staff were excellent helpful efficient and we plan to return. A special thank you to the girls at the Concierge desk ( Amy Lin & Miyuki Nishikawa for sorting out our return flights to London on Japan airlines who were also fantastic. Would recommend a trip to Japan especially this Hotel fantastic. Mark&Fiona Sullivan

One of the best parts of our stay were the staff, who were friendly and helpful at every turn! We stayed for 5 nights. The water pressure in the shower was AMAZING! The room was plenty big for three of us. Nice view of the Tokyo Tower from the balcony. Convenient to the Akabanebashi station which was great for getting around.  The downside was how expensive everything was in terms of add-ons and restaurants.  There was a charge to use the pool, breakfast was over 100 dollars one morning ( and one of us had toast and coffee only), and our first night dinner in the Chinese restaurant was nearly the same.  I would recommend this hotel based on the quality of the staff. The only reason I may not stay there again is if we choose to stay in a different area of town.

restaurants.name: Japanese Restaurant Local Drinks Higashi-Azabu Osaka
Sake to Koshitsu Izakaya Maguro Daihyo-dan ta Daihyo

amenities: Fitness Centre with Gym / Workout Room
reviews: Due to the spread of covid19, some restaurants in the hotel are closed or business hours are restricted due to the state of emergency being declared in Tokyo. The club lounge may also be open in a short time, or the venue may be changed to a large banquet hall on the basement floor, depending on the infection situation in Tokyo. However, the hotel's infection prevention measures are well taken and guests can relax with peace of mind. The number of guests is very small at present, but it is very comfortable and relaxing. This hotel can be evaluated as having a very high level of hospitality. I recommend you a room on the upper floors, with a bathroom having separate wash space and tub, which called a Japanese style.

I am writing this review as a Marriott Ambassador member and against the background of usual 150 nights per year in hotels of different groups.  I have to admit that this hotel in which I stayed 3-5 times since 2012 is one of the worst I have ever visited.  This is due to the following reasons: 1) The whole hotel is extremely old and was never really renovated 2) In winter time the rooms are extremely overheated and you have no possibility to reduce the temperature. There are a few rooms available with balcony, so you can at least open the window, but not in the standard rooms. 3) In summer time, you basically get steamed in the room as the A/C is very weak. Should you be lucky to get a room in which you can switch it to a stronger mode, you will definitely be unable to sleep

due to the noise. 4) Marriot Ambassador benefits are not really known by the staff 5) Almost impossible to find somebody who speaks English  For the price they charge, you can definitely get a better deal in Tokyo.

I had the pleasure of staying here last month during a business trip to Tokyo. The hotel is set in a nice Japanese garden in a quiet part of Tokyo but in convenient distance from down town Tokyo. Hotel was going through renovation of the business lounge but managed that situation very well by offering alternatives. There are a nice gym and pool, and great breakfast buffet.

I have been staying at this property for the last 4 to 5 years at least  3 or 4 times per year. There have been an ongoing refurbishment for several years to bring the hotel out of the 80's into the 2000's. Not all rooms are updated. I recently stayed on level 10 that felt very new, very contemporary in style & very functional for  a business traveler. I understand some floors have yet to be updated & the ground floor is undergoing major renovation work. NOTE: you do not hear any of the noise from the renovation its all done very discretely. The shuttle buses depart on time to great locations with good transport links - you can be  at Haneda using the bus & train from Shinigawa in 50 mins. Where i really struggle with this hotel is as follows; Never acknowledged as  return guest

Very rarely acknowledged as a Bonvoy Titanium elite member The menu or food on offer in the Club Lounge hasn't change in many years & recently the hours the food is available has been reduced, in fact the quantities appear to have been scaled back  Some rooms dont have a desk - reception should ask you if you need a desk & assign the right type of room The gym is very sub-standard & needs to be updated & brightened up - its more like a morgue   The hotel is clean, its comfortable, however some small elements would make this hotel stand out from the crowd.

I made the reservations at 6am and mobile checked in right away and put the arrival time at 9:00AM, of course I got a message on my app that the hotel is ready for me. But when I arrived at 9:40, I went to the Sheraton Club on the 2nd floor to check in but was told they can’t check me in there and ask me to go back to first floor reception. So I did and went on waiting on the line. Although I mobile checked in in advance but it really doesn’t do anything, I still need to give them my passport and swipe my credit card. The receptionist even ask me to filled out a registration card that I have to put down pretty much what is in my profile , my name, passport number, address, email address, telephone number, the whole nine yards. I can’t even remember when I did that last time. 20

years ago at a Motel 6 maybe? So it took almost 20 minutes for me to get check in. The receptionist never ask for what I choose for my Titanium gift. My request for an extra feather pillow never arrived, the room descriptions has a work desk, no, it has a small round table. It say double vanities, nope. Only one. The two bedside outlet are all broken. The only one working is on the dresser under the TV. It says they do turn down service. Another misinformation. When I went down to complain at the club lounge, she ready don’t understand what I want and just told me I can use the lounge and I should get something to drink. I ask her to deliver a feather pillow, but they just tried to give me a synthetic fiber pillow.  I just gave up. The food at lounge is very mediocre but it will fill you up. The reason I give this hotel a two stars is because the room is fairly nice appointed. But don’t trust the room description on their app and website.

We only stayed a few nights. The location is good - not in a noisy area but close enough to a subway station that you can easily get anywhere you need. The bed was large and comfortable. The bathroom was very modern. The rooms are small by Western standards, but definitely adequate. Amenities were nice. Breakfast is served each morning - nothing too much, but something to get you started. Everything was very clean and the staff were all lovely. We would definitely recommend it.

The hotel is good. I stayed there for like 15 nights or something. I enjoyed the room quality and the bed was wonderfully comfortable. The location is central to downtown areas with easy access to Shibuya, Roppongi, Yotsuya, Ginza. There are a few minor annoyances though.  - the water pressure in the sink is too high. I had to use both hands to try to move the sink lever as delicately as possible to avoid the water rushing out at high volumes.  - the drapes on the windows are not blackout  - while the area is central, its a red light district after 11:45

Rooms are very small, like japanese standards. A small breakfast is offered in the hall. location is very good, a few steps from the subway. Staff is very nice. Room are very clean and they provide skin care essentials for women.

We enjoyed our stay here. Bed was comfortable. Like the style. And the best part was that they provide a foot massage which was god sent after all the walking it was a relief. Location was not bad at all.

Overall, I think this was a decent stay.  I stayed here for 8 nights and I will list all the pros and cons below:  Pros: + Staff was excellent, with most speaking decent English and very friendly and responsive to requests + Location is pretty convenient with proximity to Akasaka Excel Tokyu Hotel (good if you are using the Airport Limousine Bus which will drop you off there) so it was a short 3 min walk to the hotel across the street. There are also 3 subway lines nearby: Akasaka-Mitsuke, Akasaka, and Nagatacho + Hotel gives free water, soup, and continental breakfast + They provide a free cel phone to use while you're there (I didn't know about this until after I checked into my room, which would have been great as I already bought a SIM card)  Cons (negatives): - Room was

very small. I know, this is Japan, so you were probably already expecting it, but I still didn't expect it to be this small based on the pictures I saw online.  You cannot lay a large suitcase down and open it up without leaning part of it against the wall. - The hot water in the shower was not working properly everyday. There were spurts in the shower when it would go cold really quick and then scalding hot the next second. I had to learn this pattern so I could jump out of the way when it was super hot to avoid burns.  It did this every time I took a shower, but I learned to live with it. - The carpets seemed to be dirty (the pattern on the carpet is such that you can't tell if it's really dirty, but I could tell it was dirty). - The lighting is not too bright in the room or bathroom - Since the bathroom is so small, there really isn't anywhere to place your personal toiletries other than on top of the toilet seat. - There is no electrical outlet in the bathroom, so I had to use the hairdryer in the bedroom area while sitting on my bed. - For some reason, my keycard kept getting de-magnetized. I had to get a new keycard 4 different times during my stay. This was highly inconvenient.  The guy at the front desk suggested maybe it's because I had it near other cards in my wallet or man-bag, but I made sure to keep it separate on a few other occasions and it still happened. There's something wrong with their machines, I guess.  Overall, it was a decent stay and I would definitely consider it again though due to the location.  There are a lot of great drinking/eating places nearby.

The hotel located very near to Ayase metro station, room is small (but what could one expect from Tokyo) but it has everything one would required throughout the stay. The concierge was friendly and helpful enough to assist for the automated check-in. Enjoy the quite neighbourhood of the hotel, it is being surrounded by plenty of restaurants and supermarkets. The concierge even gave me a simple map which mentioned the type of cuisine provide by the restaurants around.

The room is as small as everyone is stating but still comfortable and has everything we needed. Water, electric kettle, Wi-Fi, yukata, and toiletries for two were provided based on our reservations.  However, the front desk male attendant refused to help me book restaurant reservations. He flat out said no. I tried asking again and he went to the back and came back to say no again. When my husband went down stairs to ask, the female attendant was immediately helpful.  This treatment is clearly sexist and we will not be staying in this place again.

Few minutes walk from the metro station. Area full of restaurants, markets and shops. Very quiet and extremely clean; includes all the facilities you can imagine. The staff was very polite and helpful. Will recommend this place, no doubt!

Just near Ayase metro station, room is small but you can find every thing that you need.Bed is comfortable,pillow is good. Bath the same, all bath supplies you can find even pijamas.Personels are very help full. Around hotel you can find many restaurants and bar and cheaper according to down town.By the metro you can reach every place in half an hour.Room was very quite.Price is very good for Tokyo.They puts water daily and there is kettle in the room and coffee.
